thread.title: Back Plaid to end NHS failure, Wood tells Labour voters
thread.title_full: Back Plaid to end NHS failure, Wood tells Labour voters - BBC News

author: BBC
title: Back Plaid to end NHS failure, Wood tells Labour voters
text:
Back Plaid to end NHS failure, Wood tells Labour voters 23 October Wales politics Image caption Leanne Wood said Plaid was ready to 'face the challenges' of improving the NHS Labour voters who value the NHS should back Plaid Cymru in the assembly election, the party's leader has said.
Speaking before addressing the party's conference in Aberystwyth, Leanne Wood attacked Labour ministers' "record of failure" on health in Wales.
She said money coming to Wales due to extra spending on England's health service would go to the Welsh NHS if Plaid Cymru wins power in May 2016.
Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon will also speak on Friday.
Ms Wood said that, after 16 years of Labour rule, Wales had fewer doctors per head than elsewhere in Britain, growing waiting times for operations and people struggling with care costs.
Plaid Cymru, she promised, would recruit an extra 1,000 doctors "so that services are safe".
The party's election pledges also include scrapping care fees for the elderly and abolishing Wales' health boards, putting major hospitals under one body.
'Strong team' Plaid entered government for the first time in coalition with Labour in Cardiff Bay between 2007 and 2011, under Ms Wood's predecessor Ieuan Wyn Jones.
But Ms Wood told BBC Wales she did not want such an arrangement in 2016.
"I want to see a Plaid Cymru government," she said.
"Now I accept that forming a majority is difficult, because of the system that we have, but a Plaid Cymru minority administration would have to work with other parties in order to gets its budget and its programme through.
"I've got a strong team of candidates, a good shadow cabinet and a very strong programme of government to put before people next May."
